What is an Offer in Compromise?

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_divider color=”#1C50A4″ divider_weight=”6px” _builder_version=”4.22.0″ _module_preset=”default” width=”16%” custom_margin=”||15px||false|false” custom_padding=”||0px||false|false” global_colors_info=”{}”][/et_pb_divider][et_pb_text admin_label=”Big Text” _builder_version=”4.23″ _module_preset=”default” text_text_color=”#040011″ text_font_size=”20px” text_line_height=”1.55em” background_layout=”dark” global_colors_info=”{}”]

An offer in compromise is an agreement between a taxpayer and the IRS that settles back taxes for less than the full amount owed. The goal is a compromise that’s in the best interest of both the taxpayer and the agency.

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][et_pb_column type=”1_2″ _builder_version=”4.21.0″ _module_preset=”default” global_colors_info=”{}”][et_pb_text admin_label=”Paragraph Text” _builder_version=”4.23.1″ _module_preset=”default” text_font=”||||||||” text_text_color=”#040011″ text_line_height=”1.8em” custom_padding=”40px||||false|false” custom_padding_tablet=”40px||||false|false” custom_padding_phone=”0px||||false|false” custom_padding_last_edited=”on|phone” global_colors_info=”{}”]If you can’t afford to pay your back taxes in full or paying it all will create a financial hardship for you, you may qualify for an offer in compromise (OIC). Here are the main reasons the IRS may agree to accept less than the full amount you owe:
  • Insufficient Income and Assets: This means you don’t have enough income or assets to pay your balance due in full.
  • Hardship and Fairness: You can pay the balance due, but it would create an economic hardship or would be unfair or inequitable.
[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][/et_pb_section][et_pb_section fb_built=”1″ _builder_version=”4.22.1″ _module_preset=”default” global_colors_info=”{}”][et_pb_row _builder_version=”4.22.1″ _module_preset=”default” global_colors_info=”{}”][et_pb_column type=”4_4″ _builder_version=”4.22.1″ _module_preset=”default” global_colors_info=”{}”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”4.23.1″ _module_preset=”default” header_2_text_align=”center” header_2_text_align_tablet=”center” header_2_text_align_phone=”left” header_2_text_align_last_edited=”on|phone” global_colors_info=”{}”]

How Does the IRS Decide if a Taxpayer Qualifies for an OIC?

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_text _builder_version=”4.23″ _module_preset=”default” header_2_text_align=”center” global_colors_info=”{}”]

Once you have paid the IRS the full amount stated in an OIC agreement (and paid it within the agreed-upon time frame), your back taxes will be paid in full. Meaning, your back taxes will be considered officially resolved, even if – as is commonly the case – the OIC amount is just a tiny fraction of what you owed the IRS initially.

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_divider color=”gcid-388bea5e-1853-420f-bb0c-1bf7cb437466″ _builder_version=”4.23″ _module_preset=”default” global_colors_info=”{%22gcid-388bea5e-1853-420f-bb0c-1bf7cb437466%22:%91%22color%22%93}”][/et_pb_divider][et_pb_heading title=”OIC Payment Options” _builder_version=”4.23.1″ _module_preset=”default” title_level=”h2″ title_text_align=”center” title_font_size=”25px” title_text_align_tablet=”center” title_text_align_phone=”left” title_text_align_last_edited=”on|phone” global_colors_info=”{}”][/et_pb_heading][et_pb_text _builder_version=”4.23″ _module_preset=”default” text_orientation=”center” custom_margin=”||50px|||” text_orientation_tablet=”center” text_orientation_phone=”left” text_orientation_last_edited=”on|phone” global_colors_info=”{}”]There are two options for paying an OIC. To complete an OIC, you must select one of these options and include payment with your offer. The amount of the first and following payments will depend on the total amount you offer and which payment option you choose.[/et_pb_text][et_pb_text _builder_version=”4.23.1″ _module_preset=”default” hover_enabled=”0″ global_colors_info=”{}” sticky_enabled=”0″]
  • Lump Sum Offer: Typically, the IRS will require you to pay 20 percent of the total amount you’re offering when you submit the offer. You’ll need to pay the rest in five or fewer payments, within five or fewer months of the date the IRS accepts the offer.
  • Periodic Payment Offer: The IRS will require you to make the first payment when you submit the offer and the rest within 24 months, according to the terms of your offer.
[/et_pb_text][et_pb_text _builder_version=”4.23″ _module_preset=”default” text_orientation=”center” custom_margin=”||50px|||” text_orientation_tablet=”center” text_orientation_phone=”left” text_orientation_last_edited=”on|phone” global_colors_info=”{}”]For the IRS to accept an offer, you must file all tax returns due and be current with estimated tax payments or withholding. If you own a business and have employees, you must file all returns and be current on all your federal tax deposits.[/et_pb_text][et_pb_divider color=”gcid-388bea5e-1853-420f-bb0c-1bf7cb437466″ _builder_version=”4.23″ _module_preset=”default” locked=”off” global_colors_info=”{%22gcid-388bea5e-1853-420f-bb0c-1bf7cb437466%22:%91%22color%22%93}”][/et_pb_divider][et_pb_heading title=”How Often Does the IRS Accept Offer in Compromises?” _builder_version=”4.23.1″ _module_preset=”default” title_level=”h2″ title_text_align=”center” title_font_size=”25px” title_text_align_tablet=”center” title_text_align_phone=”left” title_text_align_last_edited=”on|phone” global_colors_info=”{}”][/et_pb_heading][et_pb_text _builder_version=”4.23″ _module_preset=”default” text_orientation=”center” custom_margin=”||50px|||” text_orientation_tablet=”center” text_orientation_phone=”left” text_orientation_last_edited=”on|phone” locked=”off” global_colors_info=”{}”]

The acceptance rate for OICs is low. Errors, omissions, and failure on the part of taxpayers to complete certain steps can often lead the IRS to reject an OIC offer. Working with a qualified tax professional can help improve one’s chances of receiving approval.

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_divider color=”gcid-388bea5e-1853-420f-bb0c-1bf7cb437466″ _builder_version=”4.23″ _module_preset=”default” locked=”off” global_colors_info=”{%22gcid-388bea5e-1853-420f-bb0c-1bf7cb437466%22:%91%22color%22%93}”][/et_pb_divider][et_pb_heading title=”How Optima Can Help with an Offer in Compromise” _builder_version=”4.23.1″ _module_preset=”default” title_level=”h2″ title_text_align=”center” title_font_size=”25px” title_text_align_tablet=”center” title_text_align_phone=”left” title_text_align_last_edited=”on|phone” locked=”off” global_colors_info=”{}”][/et_pb_heading][et_pb_text _builder_version=”4.23″ _module_preset=”default” text_orientation=”center” custom_margin=”||50px|||” text_orientation_tablet=”center” text_orientation_phone=”left” text_orientation_last_edited=”on|phone” locked=”off” global_colors_info=”{}”]Optima’s tax attorneys and licensed professionals specialize in offer-in-compromise filings. Our team will assist you from the first call all the way through to the final step that resolves your tax issues. Call for a free consultation with one of our tax professionals today and see the difference having Optima on your side can make.[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][/et_pb_section][et_pb_section fb_built=”1″ _builder_version=”4.21.0″ _module_preset=”default” background_color=”#f9f9f9″ global_module=”12172″ saved_tabs=”all” locked=”on” global_colors_info=”{}”][et_pb_row admin_label=”TrustPilot Carousel” _builder_version=”4.23.1″ _module_preset=”default” module_alignment=”center” custom_margin=”50px||50px||true|false” custom_padding=”10px||10px||true|false” global_colors_info=”{}”][et_pb_column type=”4_4″ _builder_version=”4.23.1″ _module_preset=”default” global_colors_info=”{}”][et_pb_code _builder_version=”4.21.0″ _module_preset=”default” global_colors_info=”{}”]
